item.title: Class Transformer - Definalizer + Publicizer
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

frank_: I forgot to add that Utility-classes are final classes… This to prevent inheritance. When you use them, they are normally already finished (unless you are still writing them of course). They don’t need maintainability etc. (unless you need to fix a bug, but that doesn’t really have to do with the project itself), because what they do, is just manipulate other classes’s variables etc. They don’t rely on your project… Your project rely on them.

The term ‘Utility-class’ I am not too sure about, but I atleast heard that a while ago, and adopted it to my own vocabulary (maybe ‘Helper-classes’ would be more appropriate?). So correct me on that if I am wrong…

Read full topic

item.title: Class Transformer - Definalizer + Publicizer
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

[quote=“ephemeral, post:23, topic:216571”]As I see it, this class is more of an Utility-class, than anything else. Utility-classes uses private constructors and static members (methods, variables etc.). If you take a look at java.lang.Math for instance, that class is an Utility-class, and it uses the exact pattern I just described.

If you look at it like this; there is no need for different instances of that class, because it have nothing that can change within itself, let alone affect itself compared to any other instance of it (I mean, all instances would be pretty much the “same” at all times of use).

Another thing is that it will be faster as static, than if not. Not that this is applicable in the most cases, but still. :)[/quote]for the sake of design and maintainability, nonononoononononononoo thats fkn terrible

Read full topic

item.title: Class Transformer - Definalizer + Publicizer
item.dc:creator: @system system
item.description:
@system wrote:

As I see it, this class is more of an Utility-class, than anything else. Utility-classes uses private constructors and static members (methods, variables etc.). If you take a look at java.lang.Math for instance, that class is an Utility-class, and it uses the exact pattern I just described.

If you look at it like this; there is no need for different instances of that class, because it have nothing that can change within itself, let alone affect itself compared to any other instance of it (I mean, all instances would be pretty much the “same” at all times of use).

Another thing is that it will be faster as static, than if not. Not that this is applicable in the most cases, but still.

item.title: Class Transformer - Definalizer + Publicizer
item.dc:creator: @Krichevskoy Krichevskoy
item.description:
@Krichevskoy wrote:

ownagesbot:

Obviously, the professional that Reines was he well… privatised and finalised methods and fields.

Uriko and I used one of these to grab the PID variables when he removed access to them during the Great PID-Whoring. Released the script for ST-shell. Reines was ecstatic.

Anyway, this kind of thing is better done with a Visitor. Here’s a BCEL example I pulled out of my RS folder:

[code]//By Saev - http://www.kaitnieks.com/scr/showthread.php?p=7376

import java.io.;
import java.util.jar.;
import org.apache.bcel.classfile.*;
import org.apache.bcel.Constants;

public class Publicizer extends EmptyVisitor {

public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
    
    if(args == null || args.length == 0) {
        throw new RuntimeException("this program needs a jar file as an argument");
    }
    JarFile jar = new JarFile(args[0]);
    
    for(java.util.Enumeration<JarEntry> e = jar.entries(); e.hasMoreElements(); ) {
        JarEntry entry = e.nextElement();
        
        if(!entry.isDirectory()) {
            String entryName = entry.getName();
            InputStream instream = new BufferedInputStream(jar.getInputStream(entry));
            
            if(entryName.endsWith(".class")) {
                JavaClass clazz = new ClassParser(instream, entryName).parse();
                clazz.setAccessFlags(Constants.ACC_PUBLIC);
                new DescendingVisitor(clazz, new Publicizer()).visit();
                clazz.dump(clazz.getClassName() + "_.class");
            }
            instream.close();
        }
    }
}

public void visitMethod(Method m) {
    m.isPublic(true);
    m.isPrivate(false);
    m.isFinal(false);
}

public void visitField(Field f) {
    f.isPublic(true);
    f.isPrivate(false);
}

}[/code]

Further illustrating the point, here’s one I threw together with SERP for some reason:

/*
 * Publicizer.java
 * Created on November 16, 2005, 9:13 PM
 */

package serprenamer;

import serp.bytecode.*;
import serp.bytecode.visitor.BCVisitor;

public class Publicizer extends BCVisitor {
    
    public void enterBCClass(BCClass bc) {
        bc.makePublic();
        bc.setFinal(false);
    } 
    
    public void enterBCMember(BCMember bc) {
        bc.makePublic();
        bc.setFinal(false);
    }     
}

edit: Had something similar using ASM, but I can’t find it.

Read full topic

item.title: Class Transformer - Definalizer + Publicizer
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

since they’ll only be one instance of that class, is it really needed to make it possible to have many instances?
i just dont need the point of making your class, then your main method is

public static void main(String[] args) {
    new DoStuff();
}

my main class in that peer to peer program was all static, and when i messed around with mopars SIDE, its main class ended up all static as well,

i can see frank never downloads anything i write,

i assure you, i didnt get this logic from psb, i got it from thinking about how many instances you’ll need, and how static makes you only have one instance,
